skill.name: css-development-refactor
skill.description: This skill should be used when refactoring existing CSS from inline styles or utility classes to semantic patterns. Triggers on "refactor CSS", "extract styles", "consolidate CSS", "convert inline", "clean up styles", "migrate to semantic". Transforms to semantic classes with dark mode and tests.
skill.summary: Refactor CSS from inline styles and utility classes to semantic component patterns with dark mode support
skill.author: 2389-research

security_audit.summary: This skill is a pure documentation resource for CSS refactoring workflows. All 71 static findings are false positives from markdown syntax being misinterpreted as executable code. The skill contains no actual scripts, network calls, or file operations, only examples in documentation blocks.

content.user_title: Refactor CSS to Semantic Component Patterns
content.value_statement: This skill transforms messy CSS from inline styles and repeated utility classes into organized semantic components. It extracts patterns, adds dark mode support, creates tests, and ensures maintainable styling with Tailwind composition.
actual_capabilities: Extract inline styles to semantic CSS classes with automatic naming conventions
Consolidate repeated utility class combinations into reusable components using Tailwind @apply
Add dark mode variants to all refactored CSS classes automatically
Generate test coverage for CSS components including static CSS tests and rendering tests
Update markup across multiple files to use new semantic class names
Create documentation comments for each extracted CSS component with usage examples
limitations: Requires existing CSS to refactor and cannot create designs from scratch
Works best with Tailwind CSS projects and may need adaptation for other frameworks
Cannot automatically test visual appearance and requires manual verification of styling
Does not handle complex CSS animations or transitions beyond basic hover states

output_examples.output: Created semantic class .button-primary in styles/components.css with dark mode variants, updated 8 button instances across 5 files, added 3 test cases, reduced markup by 180 characters per button

output_examples.output: Created .card component class with 12 properties including shadows, borders, padding, and dark mode variants. Updated 15 card instances across 7 files. Added static CSS tests and component rendering tests.

output_examples.input: Add dark mode to all existing button classes
output_examples.output: Added dark: variants to button-primary, button-secondary, and button-danger classes. Updated 23 components. Created before/after comparison tests. All tests passing with behavior unchanged.

best_practices: Always analyze existing components before creating new classes to avoid duplication and ensure consistency with established patterns
Include dark mode variants for all refactored classes to maintain feature parity and prepare for theme switching
Verify behavior is unchanged after refactoring by running tests and visually inspecting components in both light and dark modes
anti_patterns: Creating new semantic classes without checking if similar patterns already exist in the codebase, leading to duplicate components
Refactoring CSS without adding test coverage, making it difficult to verify behavior is preserved and catch regressions
Skipping dark mode variants during refactoring and planning to add them later, creating technical debt and inconsistent theming

faq.question: Does this skill work with CSS frameworks other than Tailwind?
faq.answer: The skill is optimized for Tailwind CSS and uses Tailwind @apply directives. It can adapt to other frameworks but may require manual adjustments to the refactoring workflow and syntax.

faq.question: Will refactoring change how my components look?
faq.answer: No. The skill performs behavior-neutral refactoring, meaning visual output should match exactly. It includes verification steps to ensure styling is preserved during the transformation.

faq.question: How does the skill decide which patterns to extract?
faq.answer: It identifies repeated utility class combinations appearing 2 or more times, checks if similar semantic classes already exist, and prioritizes high-frequency patterns for extraction to maximize code reduction.

faq.question: Can I use this skill on individual components or does it require full project access?
faq.answer: You can use it on individual components or specific files. The skill will analyze only the provided scope and suggest extractions based on patterns found within that scope.

faq.question: What testing does the skill add after refactoring?
faq.answer: It adds static CSS tests to verify classes exist and contain expected properties, plus component rendering tests to ensure classes are applied correctly. You should still manually verify visual appearance.

faq.question: How does dark mode support work if my project does not have dark mode yet?
faq.answer: The skill adds dark: variants following Tailwind conventions, preparing components for dark mode even if not currently enabled. These variants remain dormant until dark mode is activated in your project.
